instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-3332: What is 820-3332? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.PP3V3_S5: What is PP3V3_S5? PP3V3_S5 is a 3.3v power rail when the system is in an S5 soft off power state.
definitions.PP3V42_G3H: What is PP3V42_G3H? PP3V42_G3H is a power rail present when the machine is in a G3H global system hardware off state and is the first rail that should be generated in Macbooks that use it. .
definitions.PP5V_S5: What is PP5V_S5? This is a 5v power rail that is present when the machine is in an S5 soft off state..
definitions.PP5V_S0: What is PP5V_S0? PP5V_S0 is a 5v power rail present when the system is in an S0 working state..
definitions.PPVRTC_G3H: What is PPVRTC_G3H? PPVRTC_G3H is a 3.3v power rail for the RTC circuit present when the machine is in a G3H global system hardware off state. .
definitions.PP5V_S3: What is PP5V_S3? PP5V_S3 is a 5v power rail present when the system is in an S3 suspend to RAM state..
definitions.PPDCIN_G3H: What is PPDCIN_G3H? PPDCIN_G3H Is a power rail that comes directly from the laptop charger..
definitions.PP3V3_SUS: What is PP3V3_SUS? The "PP3V3_SUS" rail on a MacBook logic board is a power rail that provides a 3.3-volt supply to the suspend-to-RAM (S3 state) components. .
definitions.PP3V3_S0: What is PP3V3_S0? The "PP3V3_S0" rail in a MacBook logic board is a power rail that supplies 3.3 volts to the system when it is fully awake (S0 state). .
definitions.PP3V3_S4: What is PP3V3_S4? The "PP3V3_S4" power rail in a MacBook is used to supply 3.3 volts to certain components when the system is in the S4 power state, also known as "suspend to disk" or "hibernate." This rail is active when the MacBook is not fully off but not in an awake state, allowing for faster startup times compared to a full boot sequence. The S4 power state means Suspend to Disk: This is a low-power state where the system context is saved to disk, allowing the system to be powered down almost entirely. Upon waking, the system can restore its state from the disk, effectively resuming where it left off..
definitions.PP5V_S4: What is PP5V_S4? PP5V_S4 is a 5v power rail present when the machine is in an S4 suspend to disk state..
definitions.PPVCORE_S0_CPU: What is PPVCORE_S0_CPU? This is the primary power rail for the CPU that powers the CPU, known as CPU vcore. Without this, the machine will be braindead. .
definitions.PP1V05_S0:
What is PP1V05_S0? The PP1V05_S0 power rail is for various components on the logic board that require a 1.05V supply voltage in the S0 (on) state. This voltage rail is likely to be used by the CPU (for VCCIO), PCH (Platform Controller Hub).

.
definitions.PP1V5_S0: What is PP1V5_S0? PP1V5_S0 is a 1.5v power rail present when the machine is in an S0 working state.
definitions.PPVCORE_GPU: What is PPVCORE_GPU? This is the main power rail for the GPU. This is required for the GPU to turn on so you can get image on the display. .
definitions.PP1V8_S0: What is PP1V8_S0? PP1V8_S0 is a power rail that is present when the machine is in an S0 state, meaning it is fully turned on, not sleeping or hiberating .
definitions.PPVCORE_S0_AXG: What is PPVCORE_S0_AXG? This is vcore going to the CPUâ€™s integrated graphics processor for CPUs that have an integrated GPU. When this is missing on a device that has an integrated GPU and no discrete GPU, it usually means either no screen is detected, or the GPU integrated into the CPU is dead..
definitions.PPDCIN_G3H_ISOL: What is PPDCIN_G3H_ISOL? This is the voltage coming directly from the charger after going through a transistor. .
definitions.PP1V05_SUS: What is PP1V05_SUS? The PP1V05_SUS signal in the MacBook schematic is a power rail that supplies 1.05 volts, typically used in a suspended (SUS) state of the laptop. This state is a low-power mode where essential system functions are maintained, but the majority of the system is powered down..
definitions.PP0V75_S0_DDRVTT: What is PP0V75_S0_DDRVTT? PP0V75_S0_DDRVTT is a 0.75v power rail present when the machine is in an S0 working state .
definitions.PPVTTDDR_S3: What is PPVTTDDR_S3? PPVTTDDR_S3 is a 3.3v power rail that powers the DDR RAM when the machine is in an S3 suspend to RAM state. .
definitions.PPVIN_S5_HS_GPU_ISNS: What is PPVIN_S5_HS_GPU_ISNS? PPVIN_S5_HS_GPU_ISNS is PPBUS_G3H after going through a current sense resistor to components that create power rails for the GPU. .

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3332</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A power cycling
threads.message:
hi everyone

i have a Macbook pro 2012 820-<SIGNAL>3332_A</SIGNAL> came in as water damage device, it used to turn on with no keyboard connected so we replaced keyboard and it worked for awhile and then it stopped working, it shows green/orange light and fan spins for a second then stops then spin again and stops and keeps repeating, some voltages are pulsing such as CPU Vcore the voltage goes to 1V then drop to 0V, GPU voltage is always 0V, i got another motherboard that is fully working and nothing wrong with it i put it in the same case ( water damaged case) and once i connected all cables this motherboard stopped turning on and started doing the same behaviour and power cycling so i removed all cables except the speaker so it started working and i heard it chime so i tried to only connect J4400 and it turns on fine then i unplugged the charger and connected J5100 (Trackpad), J6701 (Mic/headphone) and J5815 (Keyboard Backlight) and once i turned it on it started to power cycle and i unplugged all the cables but no change so now both my boards are power cycling but i only want to fix the second board because it was working fine and then stopped working so one of the cables must be defective and shorted the motherboard so i believe it would be easier fix. i had a look at the board and i found <CAPACITOR>C7511</CAPACITOR> Pin 2 was burnt badly and brown so i removed the cap and checked with diode mode and it shows 0,001 and with ohm mode it shows 1.6 ohm so i think it's shorted? i tried to remove <TRANSISTOR>Q7510</TRANSISTOR>, <TRANSISTOR>Q7515</TRANSISTOR>, <TRANSISTOR>Q7550</TRANSISTOR>, <TRANSISTOR>Q7551</TRANSISTOR>, and it's still the same, 

Power rails

<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>: 12.58V Stable

<SIGNAL>PPVIN_S5_HS_COMPUTING_ISNS</SIGNAL>: 12.58V Stable

<SIGNAL>PPVIN_S5_HS_GPU_ISNS</SIGNAL> : 12.58V Stable

<SIGNAL>PPVIN_S5_HS_OTHER_ISNS</SIGNAL>: 12.58V Stable

<SIGNAL>PPDCIN_G3H</SIGNAL>: 16.80V Stable

<SIGNAL>PPDCIN_G3H_ISOL</SIGNAL>: 16.80V Stable

<SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H</SIGNAL>: 3.397V Stable

<SIGNAL>PPVRTC_G3H</SIGNAL>: 3.3V Stable

<SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL>: 5V Stable

<SIGNAL>PP5V_SUS</SIGNAL>: 5V Stable

<SIGNAL>PP5V_S4</SIGNAL>: 5V Stable

<SIGNAL>PP5V_S3</SIGNAL>: 0V

<SIGNAL>PP5V_S0</SIGNAL>: 5V dropes to 0.2V Pulsing

<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S4</SIGNAL>: 3.3V dropes to 0.2V Pulsing

<SIGNAL>PP3V3_SUS</SIGNAL>: 3.3V Stable

<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL>: 3.29V Stable

<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S3</SIGNAL>: 3.3V dtopes to 0.3V Pulsing

<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S0</SIGNAL>: 3.3V dropes to 0.1V Pulsing

<SIGNAL>PP3V3_TBTLC</SIGNAL>: 3.3V dropes to 0.2V Pulsing

<SIGNAL>PP1V05_TBTLC</SIGNAL>: 1V dropes to 0V Pulsing

<SIGNAL>PP1V05_TBTCIO</SIGNAL>: 1V dropes to 0V Pulsing

<SIGNAL>PP15V_TBT</SIGNAL>: 2.4V dropes to 1V Pulsing

<SIGNAL>PP1V8_S0</SIGNAL>: 1.8V dropes to 0V pulsing

<SIGNAL>PP1V8_S0_CPU_VCCPLL_R</SIGNAL>: 1.8V dropes to 0V Pulsing

PP1V5R1V35_MEM: 1.3V dropes to 0V Pulsing

<SIGNAL>PP1V5_S3RS0_CPUDDR</SIGNAL>: 1.3V dropes to 0V Pulsing

<SIGNAL>PP1V5_S0</SIGNAL>: 1.5V dropes to 0V Pulsing

<SIGNAL>PP1V5_S0_RIO</SIGNAL>: 1.5V dropes to 0V Pulsing

<SIGNAL>PPVTTDDR_S3</SIGNAL>: 0.6V dropes to 0V Pulsing

<SIGNAL>PP0V75_S0_DDRVTT</SIGNAL>: 0.6V dropes to 0V Pulsing

<SIGNAL>PP1V05_SUS</SIGNAL>: 1V Stable

<SIGNAL>PP1V05_S0</SIGNAL>: 1V Stable

<SIGNAL>PP1V05_PCHVCCIO_S0</SIGNAL>: 1V Stable

<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S0GPU</SIGNAL>: 3.3V dropes to 0.1V Pulsing

<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S0GPU_MISC</SIGNAL>:3.3V dropes to 0.6V Pulsing

<SIGNAL>P1V8GPU_EN</SIGNAL>: 3.3V dropes to 0V Pulsing

any help would be appreciated.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3332</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A power cycling
threads.message:
"checked with diode mode and it shows 0,001 and with ohm mode it shows 1.6 ohm so i think it's shorted?"
Do you mean between cap pins, or L7510 to ground?
VCORE has low value to ground as normal.
I hope you didn't power on the board without <CAPACITOR>C7511</CAPACITOR>; also check <RESISTOR>R7511</RESISTOR> integrity.

"i tried to only connect J4400 and it turns on fine then i unplugged the charger and connected J5100 (Trackpad), J6701 (Mic/headphone) and J5815 (Keyboard Backlight) and once i turned it on it started to power cycle"
Only trackpad can cause that symptom from these connections.

Did you try SMC bypass mode?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3332</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A power cycling
threads.message:
thanks for your reply 

"checked with diode mode and it shows 0,001 and with ohm mode it shows 1.6 ohm so i think it's shorted?"
Do you mean between cap pins, or L7510 to ground?
L7510 to ground

I hope you didn't power on the board without <CAPACITOR>C7511</CAPACITOR>; also check <RESISTOR>R7511</RESISTOR> integrity.
i tested <RESISTOR>R7511</RESISTOR> and it seems ok, i used beep mode and put each prob on one side and it beeped
and unfortunately i did try to turn it on without <CAPACITOR>C7511</CAPACITOR> :(


Did you try SMC bypass mode?
yes i tried to turn it on by holding the power button continuously and it still power cycling and the fan spins and stops but it spin faster

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3332</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A power cycling
threads.message:
"unfortunately i did try to turn it on without <CAPACITOR>C7511</CAPACITOR>"
Do NOT do it again.
You are very lucky if <TRANSISTOR>Q7510</TRANSISTOR> is not shorted now.

"<SIGNAL>PP5V_S3</SIGNAL>: 0V"
Are you really sure?
It MUST pulse at least, if you get pulses on other S3, even S0 voltages...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3332</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A power cycling
threads.message:
"unfortunately i did try to turn it on without <CAPACITOR>C7511</CAPACITOR>"
Do NOT do it again.
You are very lucky if <TRANSISTOR>Q7510</TRANSISTOR> is not shorted now.
i think L7510 is shorted to ground since i get 1.6 ohm? i soldered <TRANSISTOR>Q7510</TRANSISTOR>, <TRANSISTOR>Q7515</TRANSISTOR>, <TRANSISTOR>Q7550</TRANSISTOR>, <TRANSISTOR>Q7551</TRANSISTOR> back on the motherboard, are they should i remove them again and check the line to see if the short goes away?

"<SIGNAL>PP5V_S3</SIGNAL>: 0V"
Are you really sure?
It MUST pulse at least, if you get pulses on other S3, even S0 voltages...

sorry i was measuring on CD001 pin 1 and i got 0V but i just checked on <CAPACITOR>C7300</CAPACITOR> and i got 5V

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3332</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A power cycling
threads.message:
"i think L7510 is shorted to ground since i get 1.6 ohm"
That could be normal value for VCORE; compare with similar board...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3332</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A power cycling
threads.message:
yes i compared and it's the same. i noticed <CHIP>U1800</CHIP> gets warm, but i think it's normal? where should i start looking or testing?
is there anyway to check to see if <CHIP>U7400</CHIP> is functioning? since <CAPACITOR>C7511</CAPACITOR> was burnt the <CHIP>U7400</CHIP> can be shorted. i tried to remove <CHIP>U7400</CHIP> and turned the motherboard on and the fan started spinning and didn't stop or power cycled but it can be because no cpu vcore was there.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3332</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A power cycling
threads.message:
You get even pulse on VCORE, so should be another problem on the MLB.
Tried SMC bypass now?
Test the board alone, only USB mouse connected.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3332</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A power cycling
threads.message:
When <CHIP>U7400</CHIP> isn?t on the motherboard the voltages don?t pulse and the fan spins continuously but there is no vcore because <CHIP>U7400</CHIP> isn?t there to generate it
i put <CHIP>U7400</CHIP> back and tried smc bypass and no change still power cycling only the fan spins faster
i tried to connect a USB mouse and it lights up for a little then the light turns of but when i move the mouse it lights up again, but with the motherboard power cycling and not booting the mouse shouldn?t be working so...
and i?m testing the board alone, only the fan is connected

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3332</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A power cycling
threads.message:
If you powered on the board without <CHIP>U7400</CHIP>, trash it; CPU is dead now.
NEVER let the Gate of high-side MOSFET floating on the air!!!

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3332</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A power cycling
